words.def: Ace : A serve which lands in the receiving team's court without being touched by the receiving team, or one that is touched by only one member of the receiving team, and is not passed legally back over the net.
words.name: Ace

words.def: Assist : Usually the second of a teams three contacts, an assist is awarded for any set ball that results in a kill on the ensuing attack.
words.name: Assist

words.def: Attack : Usually the third of a teams three contacts, an attack is any attempt by the offense to score a point against the defense (this does not include free balls or over-passes).
words.name: Attack

words.def: Cut / Cut shot : attack with an extreme angle (nearly parallel to the net).
words.name: Cut

words.def: Dig : A defensive contact following an opponent's attack resulting in a playable ball.
words.name: Dig

words.def: Double contact / Double : A fault in which a player contacts the ball with two body parts consecutively.
words.name: Double contact

words.def: D.S. : The abbreviation for "defensive specialist", a position player similar to the libero.
words.name: D.S.

words.def: Dump : A surprise attack usually executed by a front row setter to catch the defense off guard; many times executed with the left hand, sometimes with the right, aimed at the donut or area 4 on the court.
words.name: Dump

words.def: Five-One : Six player offensive system where a single designated setter sets regardless of court position. He or she is responsible for the second touch on every reception of serve, and ideally every defensive play.
words.name: Five-One

words.def: Free ball / Chance ball : A ball that is passed over the net because an attack wasn't possible.
words.name: Free ball

words.def: Four-Two : Six player offense where there are two designated setters and the front row setter sets.
words.name: Four-Two

words.def: Goofy : When a player jumps with wrong foot first (while attacking)
words.name: Goofy

words.def: Joust : when the ball is falling directly on top of the net, two opposing players jump and push against the ball, trying to push it onto the other's side.
words.name: Joust

words.def: Kill : successful, legal, point-scoring play. It can be from a spike attack, tip or dump.
words.name: Kill

words.def: Mis-hit : A hit in which a player swings but does not contact the ball as intended, giving it a different speed, direction, and spin than the player intended.
words.name: Mis-hit

words.def: On-Two : When the player making the second contact on the ball decides to play the ball over the net instead of setting up his or her team mate. Most often used in court volleyball by the setter, it is often called a 'setter dump' or a 'turn and burn', but on the beach it is colloquially referred to as an 'on-two'.
words.name: On-Two

words.def: One-Two-Two Coverage : Attack coverage system where one player covers directly under the block, two players cover 1–3 meters away, and two players cover 4–5 meters away.
words.name: One-Two-Two Coverage

words.def: Opposite : The player which plays in the rotation opposite the setter and usually attacks from the right side.
words.name: Opposite

words.def: Pepper : A drill in which players hit a ball back and forth in a pass, set, spike, pass, set, spike, etc. pattern, without a net.
words.name: Pepper

words.def: Seam : When serving, the spot between passers; when attacking, the spot between blockers.
words.name: Seam

words.def: Set : The setter, located in the center front, hits the ball high above the net so that a spiker can spike it across. The setter always takes the second hit, if possible.
words.name: Set

words.def: Shank : When a player unintentionally passes a ball in a wild manner, rendering it unplayable to his or her teammates.
words.name: Shank

words.def: Shot : An offensive play in which a set ball, rather than being spiked hard, is directed to an open area of the court.
words.name: Shot

words.def: Side out : When the team that served the ball loses the rally, causing the other team to serve the next point.
words.name: Side out

words.def: Six-Two : Six player offense where there are two designated setters and the back row setter sets. Called six-two because there are two setters and six other players (two outsides, two middle hitters, and two right-side hitters)
words.name: Six-Two

words.def: Six-back : Defensive system where the player in 'six' (the middle position in the back-court) plays deep in the court covering attacks through the seam in the block, attacks over top of the block, and attacks that go high off the block. With certain blocking schemes the player in 'six' might also be responsible for deep line roll shots.
words.name: Six-back

words.def: Six-up : Defensive system where the player in 'six' (the middle position in the back-court) plays up behind the block with the responsibility of defending against a tip attack.
words.name: Six-up

words.def: Six-zero : Six player offense where there are no designated positions. Instead, the designated setter is just the player in position 3 (or sometimes 2).
words.name: Six-zero

words.def: Spike : When an offensive player attacks the ball with a one-arm motion done over the head, attempting to get a kill.
words.name: Spike

words.def: Spatch : When a player contacts the ball incorrectly during a hit causing the ball to propel unlike how the hitter intended.
words.name: Spatch

words.def: Strong side : The left side of the court, so-called because it is usually the easier side for right-handed players to attack from. Also referred to as the "On-hand" side.
words.name: Strong side

words.def: "The Gap" : A spike between area two and area three that the middle hits. It’s always the same distance from the setter no matter where the setter is positioned on the set.
words.name: "The Gap"

words.def: The "W" : A common serve receive formation at lower levels where 5 players prepare to pass with 1 designated setter. So named because from above, the 5 passers are assembled on the five points of a "W". (Alternatively, possibly a Serve Screening formation by the serving team, also named for resembling a W)
words.name: The "W"

words.def: Whiff - When a hitter swings for the ball and slightly grazes it with his middle finger and ring finger.
words.name: Whiff

words.def: Two-Three Coverage : Attack coverage system where two players cover 1–2 meters away from the block, and three players cover 2–4 meters away.
words.name: Two-Three Coverage

words.def: Weak Side : The right side of the court, so-called because it is generally easier for right-handed players to attack from the left ('strong') side. Also known "off-hand" side.
words.name: Weak Side

words.def: A : A back row set aimed at the left side of the court [A|B||C|D]. Also could be a quick set to the middle.
words.name: A

words.def: B : A back row set aimed to the left side of the middle of the court [A|B||C|D].
words.name: B

words.def: Back-Two: A ball set relatively high and to the middle or to the right side hitter, directly behind the setter.
words.name: Back-Two

words.def: Back-One: A ball set relatively low (or quick) to the middle hitter or to the right side hitter, directly behind the setter.
words.name: Back-One

words.def: Bick : Similar to the "Pipe", but set very low
words.name: Bick

words.def: C : A back row set aimed to the right side of the middle of the court [A|B||C|D].
words.name: C

words.def: Chaos: An outside in which the middle runs a one, the outside comes for a two off the middle's shoulder, and the weak side runs around the back to hit an outside 3.
words.name: Chaos

words.def: D : A back row set aimed at the right side of the court [A|B||C|D].
words.name: D

words.def: Five : Same as a four set, but to the outside.
words.name: Five

words.def: Four/Back : A high set to the weak/right side hitter.
words.name: Four

words.def: Go : A set to the outside hitter, higher than a shoot but lower and faster than a hut.
words.name: Go

words.def: Hut / Loop : A lower set to the outsider hitter. Higher than a shoot.
words.name: Hut

words.def: Jones : A variation of "Chaos" where the middle runs a one, the outside comes for a "back 2," and the weakside comes around to hit an "outside 3." The setter may choose to set the ball to any of the three hitting options. This play is designed so that the setter is able to accommodate the set according to where the block is positioned.
words.name: Jones

words.def: One / Quick / Fifty One : A type of middle hit when the middle jumps before the setter sets, with the ball being set directly to the middle hitter's hand.
words.name: One

words.def: Pipe : A back row set aimed at the middle of the court between a B and a C-ball [A|B|^|C|D].
words.name: Pipe

words.def: Shocker: A attack in which the Middle runs a one, the Opposite comes for a two off the middle's shoulder, and the Outside runs/slides around to hit a back-two.
words.name: Shocker

words.def: Shoot : A variation on the quick set except instead of setting the ball to the middle the ball is set to the outside hitter.
words.name: Shoot

words.def: Step / Slide : An attack where the hitter fakes a quick-set (one) approach with his/her first step and subsequently chases the ball behind the setter and parallel to the net, jumps off one foot and hits the ball close to the antenna on the weak-side.
words.name: Step / Slide

words.def: Ten : A ball set for a back row attack.
words.name: Ten

words.def: Three / Thirty-Three : A quick lower set to the outside.
words.name: Three

words.def: Thirty-Two: An attack where the hitter fakes a quick-set (one) approach with his/her first step and subsequently chases the ball in front of the setter and parallel to the net, jumps off one foot and hits the ball in the outside 3 position. Generally used as adapted version of the Slide for left-handed hitters.
words.name: Thirty-Two

words.def: Two : A ball set to the middle hitter. Also, a "back two" is the same set set behind the setter.
words.name: Two

words.def: Cross (X) : A play in which the middle hitter jumps for a one, and the weak-side hitter, having moved to the middle of the court, takes an approach for a two at the same location.
words.name: Cross (X)

words.def: Thirty One / Inside Shoot : A play in which the middle hitter runs a one ball 5 to 10 feet away from the setter.
words.name: Thirty One

words.def: Stack / Tandem : Similar to the "cross" but the outside hitter hits the two ball.
words.name: Stack

words.def: Thirty Stack : A play in which the middle hitter runs a Thirty One and the Outside Hitter runs a Thirty Two
words.name: Thirty Stack

words.def: Shaft : A deep pipe set, generally set high.
words.name: Shaft

words.def: Middle-finger Ball : When the libero takes an approach and jumps as if to hit a one ball, making as much noise as possible to distract the other team. This will hopefully cause blockers to jump with the libero, despite there being no threat of attack. Usually used by a team winning by a significant margin.
words.name: Middle-finger Ball

words.def: Beach dig : A dig made using both hands and fingers to surround the ball, squeeze and actually slightly lift the ball. Allowed when defending against a hard hit on the beach.
words.name: Beach dig

words.def: Bump : Similar in motion to a pass, but used to set a ball for an attack.
words.name: Bump

words.def: Chicken wing : When a defending player is forced to react very quickly to a ball coming at their upper torso, the player may lift a bent arm in the shape of a chicken wing to dig the ball.
words.name: Chicken wing

words.def: Chop Shot : A type of attack usually executed on the beach, instead of contacting behind the ball the player turns their hand sideways and chops the side of the ball, creating side spin and a sharp sideways trajectory along the net. Most easily done with the right hand on the right side, and the left hand on the left side.
words.name: Chop Shot

words.def: Cobra : With the fingers extended straight and stiff, the ball is poked with the fingertips.
words.name: Cobra

words.def: Crepe : When a player digs the ball by extending his or her foot flat on the floor, letting the ball bounce off the top of the foot.
words.name: Crepe

words.def: Dinosaur-Dig : When one attempts to block a ball but it falls down between them and the net, so they bring their arms down in front of them like a T-Rex and play the ball up with the backs of their wrists.
words.name: Dinosaur-Dig

words.def: Flipper : A reaching contact made with the outstretched back of the hand in a flipping motion. Popularized by beach player Andy Fishburn.
words.name: Flipper

words.def: Floater/Float : A non-spinning serve characterized by unpredictable, erratic movement during flight caused by airflow interacting with the seams of the ball. Similar to a knuckleball in baseball.
words.name: Floater

words.def: Gator : A defensive digging technique used on the beach in the defense of a hard hit ball. The hands are formed into the shape of 2 gator jaws. The maneuver involves digging the ball with the bottom hand and then directing it with the upper hand.
words.name: Gator

words.def: J-Stroke : an emergency play made either running or diving, often with one hand, where a player has to reach well in front of them to contact the ball and follow through in a 'J' motion in order to send the ball back over their head.
words.name: J-Stroke

words.def: Jay-pass : a forearm or overhead pass that places the setter in a position to only be able to set the passer who initiated the pass. Generally passed low to the ground and immediately in front of the passer.
words.name: Jay-pass

words.def: Jump float : A float serve with a small hop/jump.
words.name: Jump float

words.def: Jump Serve / Jump spin : a serve made famous by Karch Kiraly; the server tosses the ball high into the air about 3~5 feet away from himself, flicking the wrist making top spin on the ball then taking a spike approach and contacting the ball while in mid air snapping the wrist to cause great forward spin to allow the ball to suddenly drop when the opponent is going to pass the ball.
words.name: Jump Serve

words.def: Kong : A one-handed block, usually because the blocker is late. Initially popularized by Randy Stoklos.
words.name: Kong

words.def: Pancake : When a player digs the ball by extending his or her hand flat on the floor, palm facing down, letting the ball bounce off the back of the hand.
words.name: Pancake

words.def: Pokey : A ball contacted with the knuckles especially on the beach.
words.name: Pokey

words.def: Roll Shot : An attacker hits the set softly putting extreme topspin on the ball so that it will clear the block and drop quickly and directly over the block.
words.name: Roll Shot

words.def: Sprawl : A type of dig in which the player does not dive forward, but rather places his hands on the ground and pushes his body forward and down. Similar to diving for a ball, but not actually leaving the ground.
words.name: Sprawl

words.def: Sky ball : A unique underhand serve in which the ball is shot unusually high into the air above the opposing team's court in the attempt to confuse the receiver.
words.name: Sky ball

words.def: Thunder: A spike or attack that requires a lot of force from the arm, and a very high jump. The ball is hit steeply downwards from the point of contact, and is very difficult to receive.
words.name: Thunder

words.def: Tip : A softer or off-speed finesse attack, usually committed with more of the fingers and fingertips than the whole hand as used in an attack.
words.name: Tip

words.def: Wipe / Swipe : When one player pushes the ball against the opponents block and physically wipes the ball out of bounds. Similar to a tool.
words.name: Wipe

words.def: Steino : A 3 Knuckle pokey shot in beach Volleyball made famous by AVP Pro and USA Olympian Stein Metzger. Stein Metzger gives credit to the introduction of the shot on the AVP Pro tour to Eduardo Jorge "Anjinho" Bacil Filho better known as Anjinho Bacil.
words.name: Steino

words.def: Bang / Bounce / Thump: A ball spiked very hard with a steep downward angle.
words.name: Bang

words.def: Beer: When an attacked ball goes through a defenders legs. After being "Beered" the defender then owes the attacker a beer.
words.name: Beer

words.def: Blash: When a ball is blocked and the ball travels faster from the blocker to the floor than the attacker to the block. Made famous by Cameron Billingham, the term comes from a combination of the words 'Block' and 'Smash'.
words.name: Blash

words.def: Block City: A fictional place that players claim to go when they are blocking very well. Also known as Turkey Town. (See "Stuff Turkey").
words.name: Block City

words.def: Butter / Nectar / Sauce / Cheddar Biscuits : A perfect set.
words.name: Butter

words.def: Chowder/Chum : A badly mangled set.
words.name: Chowder/Chum

words.def: Chick Impressor: When an aggressive kill setup by an over passed ball impresses physically attractive bystanders.
words.name: Chick Impressor

words.def: Chicken Presser: See Chick Impressor.
words.name: Chicken Presser

words.def: Crab Defense: When a player is serving, the opposing three passers shuffle side to side and pinch their hands like crabs to distract the server.
words.name: Crab Defense

words.def: Deep Dish/Chicago style pizza/Evan set : An illegal set that is held excessively long, typically set from below the shoulders and seen in beach volleyball.
words.name: Deep Dish/Chicago style pizza/Evan set

words.def: Dirt Dessert: When a player gets a kill so sweet, it's almost comparable to the utter sweetness of a classic Dirt Dessert.
words.name: Dirt Dessert

words.def: Double-double : When a player accumulates double-digit amounts in two of five statistical categories—aces, kills, blocks, digs, and assists—during one match.
words.name: Double-double

words.def: Easy : What a defending player should yell at the top of their lungs when successfully digging a very hard hit attack or perfectly passing a hard serve, as if to say that the attacking/serving player is easy.
words.name: Easy

words.def: Facial / Six-Pack / Tattoo/ Dome : When a defending player gets hit in the face with the ball either from an attack by the opposing team or by a deflection off the block. The term "six-pack" refers to the dizzying sensation of being hit directly in the head or face by a volleyball as being analogous to the dizzying sensation of having drunk a six pack of beer. The abdominal muscles are sometimes referred to as a "six-pack," so getting hit in the stomach by the ball is getting 'six-packed.' The term "tattoo" refers to marks left on the skin of the hit player by the seams/lettering on the ball.
words.name: Facial

words.def: Fishing: Making illegal contact with the net.
words.name: Fishing

words.def: Hands : Hand setting. Someone with "nice hands" sets well.
words.name: Hands

words.def: Heat : Speed. Used to describe a hard-hit ball.
words.name: Heat

words.def: House / Stuff / Roof : When the defensive player blocks a ball so hard that it is immediately returned to the hitter and goes straight to the floor.
words.name: House

words.def: Hubby-wife / Campfire : In beach volleyball, when a serve drops between two players because the players don't decide in time who will pass it.
words.name: Hubby-wife

words.def: Jet Nai Heed : The act of intentionally blocking a spike from the opposing team.
words.name: Jet Nai Heed

words.def: Jungleball / Barbecue ball / Picnic ball : A volleyball game played by inexperienced players with little ball control.
words.name: Jungleball

words.def: Killing Ants : when a player digging a hit passes the ball directly into the ground
words.name: Killing Ants

words.def: Killshot : on a serve or a swing when the ball hits the passers neck or chest region, in between digging and getting facialed
words.name: Killshot

words.def: Lombardo: A beach volley player who demonstrates a gross lack of skill, knowledge, or style. "That lombardo has been throwing party balls all day!".
words.name: Lombardo

words.def: Nail : A perfect pass.
words.name: Nail

words.def: O.T. : When an attacker hits the ball over top of the blocker and it lands in front of the defense.
words.name: O.T.

words.def: Overkill : When an overpass (or a free ball) occurs and the opposing team attacks the ball for a kill.
words.name: Overkill

words.def: Paintbrush / Whiff / Spatch : A mishit — when a player attempts to hit (or spike) the ball with the open hand and nearly misses the ball, only contacting the ball with his/her fingers resulting in a backspin on the ball.
words.name: Paintbrush

words.def: Pancake Lake : An imaginary place a player (normally libero) goes when they repeatedly pancake a tipped ball or ball headed for the ground.
words.name: Pancake Lake

words.def: Party Ball : Opportunity for a front row player to return an overpassed ball with a hit.
words.name: Party Ball

words.def: Phone Booth : When a blocker's hands seal off every possible attack angle on a set ball. Often referred to as, "It's like trying to hit out of a phone booth."
words.name: Phone Booth

words.def: Pineapple : An attack on the second contact by the setter of a team, usually with the right hand designed to land in the deep corner of the court. Often done without looking at the target for deception. Made famous by USA setter Lloy Ball when playing in college.
words.name: Pineapple

words.def: Popcorn setting/Sprinkler : When an unskilled setter is sending sets in a random pattern (like popcorn being popped, or like a water sprinkler on the grass).
words.name: Popcorn setting

words.def: Quadruple-double : When a player amasses a double-digit total in four of five statistical categories—aces, kills, blocks, digs, and assists—during a match.
words.name: Quadruple-double

words.def: Quintuple-double : When a player accomplishes ten or more aces, kills, blocks, digs, and assists during a match.
words.name: Quintuple-double

words.def: Rainbow : A shot especially on the beach that is hit over the head of the defender to the far corner and lands cleanly. Also known as a Jumbo Shrimp (due to the arc/shape of the shot).
words.name: Rainbow

words.def: Rufio : A cheer done in volleyball, famous from the movie Hook, where a player blocks the opposing player straight down on the opposing players' side. Players scream, Rufio, Rufio, Ru-fi-OOOOOO!!!
words.name: Rufio

words.def: Scrappy : Referring to a team that doesn't let a single ball hit the ground without much effort. (used positively)
words.name: Scrappy

words.def: Shag : Picking up and collecting scattered volleyballs.
words.name: Shag

words.def: Skunk/Skunk rule : A win that occurs when a team scores 7 points while the opposition has not scored. Similar to the mercy rule.
words.name: Skunk/Skunk rule

words.def: Spalding: when the hitters hit the ball and it hits the opposing defensive team in the face or on their body. Spalding refers to the letters of the ball staying on the players face because it hit them so hard.
words.name: Spalding

words.def: Spiketown/Bouncetown: A fictional place that a hitter claims to go to when he/she gets an impressive kill that bounces very high and no one can return (a lot of times near the 3 meter line.)
words.name: Spiketown/Bouncetown

words.def: Stuff Turkey: A stuff block in which the ball hits the opponents' floor before the blocker does; When such an event occurs, a player is said to have had his turkey stuffed.
words.name: Stuff Turkey

words.def: Sui-set: A ball set too close to the net directly in to the hands of a waiting blocker; The attacker will get blocked most of the time.
words.name: Sui-set

words.def: Tool / Use : An attack which is deflected off an opponent (usually during a block) and is unplayable resulting in a point for the attacking team (also called a bounce off).
words.name: Tool

words.def: Tough Bacon : Any ball that is played in a way that makes it difficult for the next player to successfully play the ball. For instance, after a bad set the intended hitter might remark "that was tough bacon". Similarly, a setter might remark as such after a bad pass, or a passer might remark as such after a difficult serve.
words.name: Tough Bacon

words.def: Trap : A ball set too close to the net where the hitter typically gets stuffed.
words.name: Trap

words.def: Triple-double : When a player, during a single match, scores at least ten times in three of five statistical categories: Aces, kills, blocks, digs, and assists.
words.name: Triple-double

words.def: Vegas Line: A kill resulting from a powerful hard-line spike that penetrates or beats the opponents' line block. So-named after Sean Rosenthal, a member of the AVP delivered such a memorable kill in Las Vegas, 2005.
words.name: Vegas Line

words.def: Waffle: Another term for a mishit attack that results in backspin on the ball.
words.name: Waffle

words.def: Waterfall Ball: When a players hit goes inside the block of the opposing team and falls down on their side much like a waterfall.
words.name: Waterfall Ball

words.def: Yummy: When a player gets a kill out of an overpass from the opposing team.
words.name: Yummy
